posts._title: Donald G. Jackson & R.J. Kizer – Hell Comes to Frogtown (1988)
posts.title: Hell Comes to Frogtown
posts.excerpt: Quote:After a nuclear war, the survivors are divided between horribly mutated beings who live on desolate reservations and fertile women who are searching for scarce virile men in order to multiply and start a new human society.

posts.title: Pourvu qu’on ait l’ivresse…
posts.excerpt: Quote:In a ballroom dance, a shy young man tries to find a young girl to dance with … The clumsiness and ease of the dancers, the hesitations of the flirters, an atmosphere of celebration and derision, filmed with sensitivity, without comment or dialogue.

posts._title: Manfred Kirchheimer – Stations of the Elevated (1981)
posts.title: Stations of the Elevated
posts.excerpt: Quote:This 1979 documentary is one of my all time favorites. The structure is as simple as theycome. Footage of the various New York subways which run on elevated tracks is set tothe music of Charles Mingus (with a little Duke Ellington thrown in for good measure)
